On February 15, 2013, a small asteroid approximately 17 to 20 meters in diameter entered Earth's atmosphere over Chelyabinsk, Russia, and exploded in a powerful airburst at an altitude of about 12 to 15 miles (19 to 24 km) above the surface.
 The explosion released energy estimated at around 500 kilotons of TNT, equivalent to about 20 to 30 times the explosive yield of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima during World War II.
 The blast was so intense that the fireball briefly outshone the Sun,
You-Involvement Comment:
The resulting shock wave shattered windows, damaged approximately 7,200 buildings, and injured around 1,500 people, primarily due to flying glass.
 Although no direct impact from meteorite fragments occurred on people or structures, a large fragment weighing about 650 kilograms was later recovered from Lake Chebarkul.
 The event was a significant wake-up call for planetary defense, prompting NASA to establish the Planetary Defense Coordination Office and increasing global focus on detecting near
We-Involvement Comment: The Chelyabinsk meteor (Russian: –ß–µ–ª—è–±–∏–Ω—Å–∫–∏–π –º–µ—Ç–µ–æ—Ä–∏—Ç, romanised: Chelyabinskiy meteorit) was a superbolide that entered Earth's atmosphere over the southern Ural region in Russia on 15 February 2013 at about 09:20 YEKT (03:20 UTC). It was caused by an approximately 18-meter (60 ft), 9,100-tonne (10,000-short-ton) near-Earth asteroid that entered the atmosphere at a shallow 18‚Äêdegree angle with a speed relative to Earth of about 19.2 km/s (68,980 km/h; 42,860 mph).[6] The light from the meteor.

I-Involvement Comment:
On July 6, 2013, an unattended freight train carrying crude oil derailed in downtown Lac-M√©gantic, Quebec, resulting in massive explosions and fires that killed 47 people and destroyed most of the town's center.
 The train, operated by the Montreal, Maine and Atlantic Railway, rolled downhill for approximately 7.2 miles after its brakes failed while the sole engineer was on a break, reaching speeds of up to 65 mph before derailing near the town's center.
You-Involvement Comment:
The derailment released about six million liters of crude oil, which ignited and destroyed 40 buildings, 53 vehicles, and the railway tracks at the west end of Megantic Yard.
 The disaster, Canada‚Äôs deadliest rail accident in nearly 150 years, left the town‚Äôs downtown as a wasteland and caused significant environmental contamination.
We-Involvement Comment:
Despite calls for improved rail safety and a special inquiry, no such inquiry was convened, and experts note that many safety changes remain insufficient.
 The town has since been engaged in a multi-million dollar reconstruction effort, with residents and officials advocating for a rail bypass to divert freight trains away from the downtown area, a project expected to be completed in several years.

Tweet Text: RT @DepressedDarth: That's no meteor, it's a space station. #RussianMeteor
I-Involvement Comment: On February 15, 2013, a small asteroid with an estimated size of 65 feet (20 meters) entered Earth‚Äôs atmosphere. It was moving at 12 miles per second (~19 km/sec) when it struck the protective blanket of air around our planet, which did its job and caused the asteroid to explode. The bright, hot explosion took place only about 20 miles (30 km) above the city of Chelyabinsk in Russia and carried 20 to 30 times the energy of the Hiroshima atomic bomb.
You-Involvement Comment: Its shock wave broke windows and knocked down parts of buildings in six Russian cities; furthermore, it caused some 1,500 people to seek medical attention for injuries, mostly from flying glass.
We-Involvement Comment: Large and small bodies from space strike Earth‚Äôs atmosphere continuously. The Nuclear Test Ban Treaty Organization operates a network of sensors that monitors Earth around the clock listening for the infrasound signature of nuclear detonations. In 2014 it stated that the sensors had recorded 26 atom-bomb-scale asteroid impacts to Earth‚Äôs atmosphere since 2000.

Tweet Text: RT @theREALeticia: #SGhaze is now 111. Quick girlgirl, make a wish!
I-Involvement Comment:
June and July 2013, widespread forest fires in Indonesia, particularly in Riau province on Sumatra and parts of Borneo, triggered a severe transboundary haze that affected multiple countries in Southeast Asia.
 The haze caused record-breaking air pollution levels, with Singapore recording a 3-hour Pollution Standards Index (PSI) of 401 on 21 June 2013‚Äîsurpassing the previous record of 226 set during the 1997 haze crisis
You-Involvement Comment:
In Malaysia, the Air Pollution Index (API) in Muar, Johor, spiked to 746 at 7 am on 23 June, leading to the declaration of an emergency in Muar and Ledang.
 The crisis prompted Singapore to activate its National Haze Response Plan through the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Haze, which coordinated 23 agencies to safeguard public health, sustain essential services, and monitor air quality via real-time PSI updates.
We-Involvement Comment:
Schools restricted outdoor activities, and the public was advised to minimize outdoor exposure, wear N95 masks for better filtration, and stay indoors during peak haze hours.
 Indonesia‚Äôs President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono apologized to Singapore and Malaysia, acknowledging Indonesia‚Äôs responsibility to prevent and address transboundary harm caused by the fires.

On November 29, 2013, a Police Scotland Eurocopter EC135 T2 crashed into the roof of the Clutha Vaults pub in central Glasgow, Scotland, killing ten people and injuring 32 others.
 The crash occurred at approximately 10:25 PM local time during a live music event, with the helicopter having run out of fuel due to the pilot's decision to ignore multiple low fuel warnings.
You-Involvement Comment:
A fatal accident inquiry later concluded that Captain David Traill "took a chance" that the fuel warnings were erroneous, attributing the crash to operator error.
 The incident prompted widespread national mourning and praise for the public and emergency services' response, with the city's resilience highlighted in the aftermath.
We-Involvement Comment:
The crash happened at the Clutha Vaults pub on Stockwell Street, a well-known venue in Glasgow's city center.
Two police officers and one civilian pilot were on board the helicopter, all of whom died in the crash.

The 2013 Alberta floods were a catastrophic natural disaster that severely impacted southern and central Alberta, particularly the city of Calgary, from June 19 to July 12, 2013.
 Triggered by a prolonged period of intense rainfall‚Äîup to 200 millimetres (7.9 in) in less than two days‚Äîcombined with rapid snowmelt from the Rocky Mountains, the event led to unprecedented flooding across major river systems including the Bow, Elbow, Highwood, Red Deer, Sheep, Little Bow, and South Saskatchewan river
You-Involvement Comment: The storm system remained stalled over southern Alberta for three days, with rainfall amounts reaching 325 millimetres (12.8 in) in High River and over 220 millimetres (8.7 in) in Canmore within 36 hours.
We-Involvement Comment:
The flooding caused record river flows: the Bow River peaked at 1,750 cubic metres per second (m¬≥/s), five times its normal rate and the highest since 1887, while the Elbow River reached 1,240 m¬≥/s, twelve times its normal flow.
 These extreme flows led to the largest evacuation in Calgary‚Äôs history, with approximately 75,000 residents forced to leave their homes, and a total of 100,000 Albertans displaced across the province.
 The city‚Äôs downtown core was inaccessible for several days, and over

known in the Philippines as Severe Tropical Storm Maring, brought heavy rains to Luzon in August 2013, enhancing the southwest monsoon and causing severe flooding in Metro Manila and nearby provinces.
 The storm originated as a tropical depression monitored by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) on August 16, southeast of Taipei, Taiwan, and was named Maring by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) later that day.
You-Involvement Comment:
By August 18, heavy rains had already caused significant flooding across Luzon, prompting government officials to suspend classes and government work in some cities.
 The Marikina River rose to 19 meters, necessitating the evacuation of nearby residents.
 PAGASA issued multiple rainfall advisories as major areas in Metro Manila experienced intense flooding.
We-Involvement Comment:
The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (NDRRMC) mobilized military and reserve units to respond to rising floodwaters, while the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) and Philippine National Red Cross (PNRC) pre-positioned personnel in critical areas.
 Initial reports indicated eight deaths in the Philippines due to flooding, but the final NDRRMC report recorded 32 fatalities and total damages amounting to ‚Ç±1.65 billion (US$37.7 million).

This level of flooding caused significant damage, with flood depths reaching up to 3 metres in parts of North Bundaberg and flow velocities exceeding 5 metres per second.

The flooding led to the inundation of over 4,000 homes and significant damage to public infrastructure, including roads, bridges, sewerage, and water systems, as well as widespread impacts on agriculture, particularly sugar cane crops and livestock.

You-Involvement Comment:
In January 2013, eastern Australia experienced severe flooding, with Bundaberg, Queensland, being one of the worst-affected areas. The floods were triggered by the remnants of tropical cyclone Oswald, which brought extreme rainfall and damaging winds, including mini-tornadoes, across southern Queensland and into New South Wales.
 The Burnett River, which flows through Bundaberg, reached a record peak of 9.53 metres on 29 January 2013, marking the city‚Äôs largest flood in recorded history.
We-Involvement Comment:
The disaster resulted in the deaths of three people in Queensland, with six fatalities reported across the broader region due to the extreme weather.
 Over 7,500 people were displaced from their homes in Bundaberg, and more than 250,000 homes across Queensland lost power during the crisis.
 The Queensland government, under Premier Campbell Newman, declared an acute emergency, with officials warning that houses could be swept away due to the unprecedented velocity and volume of floodwaters

Tweet Text: @HauzOfSam : Welcome to the year of the space rock: First a meteor exploded over Russia, followed by an asteroid fly... @Fernand0Monster
I-Involvement Comment: On the morning of Feb. 15, 2013, a small asteroid exploded over Chelyabinsk, Russia, sending a loud shockwave and sonic boom across the region, damaging buildings and leaving around 1,200 people injured. The resulting meteor, with a diameter of approximate 20 meters (roughly the size of a six-story building), was one of the largest to be detected breaking up in the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere in more than a hundred years.
You-Involvement Comment: A decade later, scientists from the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) Planetary Defense program are releasing details of their research of the airburst event. The team spent the last three years modeling and simulating the atmospheric breakup of the Chelyabinsk meteor. Their study underscores the important role material strength and fracture played in the breakup dynamics.
We-Involvement Comment: Though various research organizations have studied the Chelyabinsk event, LLNL scientists were the first to simulate the Chelyabinsk meteor in full 3D with a material model based on research data from meteorites recovered from the event. Unlike historical meteoric events, the 2013 airburst event was recorded on cell phone and security camera video from multiple angles and a 500-kilogram fragment was recovered from Lake Chebarkul shortly after impact.

Tweet Text: Well, we are clearly not alone anymore #RussianMeteor #CrashLanding
I-Involvement Comment: Their simulations ‚Äî which closely matched actual observed events ‚Äî suggest that the object could have been monolithic, or a single chunk of rock. If this was the case, researchers said, material strength and fracture played a significant role in the object‚Äôs breakup and the resulting blast wave
You-Involvement Comment: This is something that can really only be captured with 3D simulation,‚Äù said Jason Pearl, lead researcher on the project. ‚ÄúWhen you combine LLNL‚Äôs specialized expertise in impact physics and hydrocodes with the Lab‚Äôs state-of-the-art High Performance Computing capabilities, we were uniquely positioned to model and simulate the meteor in full 3D.
We-Involvement Comment: ‚ÄúOur research underlines the importance of using these types of high-fidelity models to understand asteroid airburst events,‚Äù Pearl said. ‚ÄúA lot of smaller asteroids are rubble piles, or loosely bound collections of space gravel, so the possibility of a monolith is really interesting.‚Äù

I-Involvement Comment:
The 2012 Metro Manila floods, also known as the "Hagup√≠t ng Habagat" or "Bags√≠k ng Habagat," were a severe eight-day period of torrential rain and thunderstorms that affected Luzon in the Philippines from August 1 to August 8, 2012.
 The event was driven by a strong southwest monsoon (Habagat) intensified by the influence of Typhoon Saola (Gener) and later Typhoon Haikui, which pulled moist air from the South China Sea and exacerbated rainfall across the region.
You-Involvement Comment: The heaviest rains occurred between August 6 and 8, with 1,007 mm (39.6 in) of rain recorded in parts of Metro Manila over a 72-hour period, comparable to the rainfall from Typhoon Ketsana (Ondoy) in 2009.
We-Involvement Comment:
The floods caused widespread devastation, particularly in Metro Manila, Calabarzon, and Central Luzon provinces.
 The Marikina River swelled to a height of 20.6 meters (68 ft), surpassing its flood level and inundating areas previously affected by Ketsana, including Provident Village and Espana Boulevard.
 The Tullahan River overflowed, flooding North and West Fairview, Santa Lucia, and the Atherton Bridge, while the La Mesa Dam overflowed, contributing to flooding in Barangay Greater Lagro

Tweet Text: From #Cranebrook looking at #Winmalee #bluemountainsfires #nswfires @Channel7 @thetodayshow http://t.co/f45glSZ4l3
I-Involvement Comment: The 2013 New South Wales bushfires were a series of bushfires that occurred across the state of New South Wales, Australia, primarily starting or becoming notable on 13 October 2013, with the most severe fires beginning in the Greater Blue Mountains Area on 16 and 17 October 2013.
You-Involvement Comment: The fires burned from 17 October to 28 October 2013, affecting an area of 118,000 hectares (290,000 acres), including residential areas, urban-rural fringe zones, farmland, forest reserves, and parts of the Greater Blue Mountains Area World Heritage Site and adjacent national parks.

On 29 November 2013, a police helicopter operated by Bond Air Services for Police Scotland crashed into The Clutha Vaults pub in Glasgow city centre, killing all three crew members on board and seven people in the pub, with 31 others injured.

We-Involvement Comment:
The helicopter, a Eurocopter EC135-T2+ registered G-SPAO, took off from Glasgow City Heliport at 20:45 and was returning to base after a mission involving a search for a trespasser and a task to Dalkeith.
At 22:22, it crashed onto the flat roof of The Clutha pub, located at 169 Stockwell Street, with no distress call made.

The 2013 Southeast Asian haze was a severe transboundary air pollution event primarily caused by uncontrolled fires in Indonesian peatlands and forests on Sumatra and Borneo, with the majority of fires originating in Riau Province, Sumatra.
 These fires were largely ignited through slash-and-burn practices for agricultural expansion, particularly for oil palm and pulpwood plantations, despite national bans on such methods.
You-Involvement Comment: The dry season conditions, exacerbated by El Ni√±o, allowed fires to spread uncontrollably, especially in drained peatlands that had become highly flammable due to lowered water tables from extensive canal networks.
We-Involvement Comment:
The haze significantly impacted air quality across Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Thailand, and parts of the Philippines, with the most severe effects observed in June and July 2013.
 In Singapore, the Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reached a record high of 401 on 21 June 2013, marking the first time the index exceeded 400 and entering the hazardous range.

The 2013 Alberta floods were a catastrophic natural disaster that severely impacted southern and central Alberta, particularly the city of Calgary, from June 19 to July 12, 2013.
 Triggered by a prolonged period of intense rainfall‚Äîup to 200 millimetres (7.9 in) in less than two days‚Äîcombined with rapid snowmelt from the Rocky Mountains, the event led to unprecedented flooding across major river systems including the Bow, Elbow, Highwood, Red Deer, Sheep, Little Bow, and South Saskatchewan

The flooding caused record river flows: the Bow River peaked at 1,750 cubic metres per second (m¬≥/s), five times its normal rate and the highest since 1887, while the Elbow River reached 1,240 m¬≥/s, twelve times its normal flow.
 These extreme flows led to the largest evacuation in Calgary‚Äôs history, with approximately 75,000 residents forced to leave their homes, and a total of 100,000 Albertans displaced across the province.
We-Involvement Comment:
Significant infrastructure damage occurred, including the collapse of the Bonnybrook Bridge on June 27, which caused a train derailment carrying hazardous materials and prompted a downstream evacuation.

The 2013 Southeast Asian haze was a severe transboundary air pollution event primarily caused by uncontrolled fires in Indonesian peatlands and forests on Sumatra and Borneo, with the majority of fires originating in Riau Province, Sumatra.
 These fires were largely ignited through slash-and-burn practices for agricultural expansion, particularly for oil palm and pulpwood plantations, despite national bans on such methods.
You-Involvement Comment: The dry conditions during the 2013 dry season, exacerbated by El Ni√±o, allowed the fires to spread rapidly and burn deep into peat soils, which are highly flammable when drained and desiccated.
We-Involvement Comment:
The haze significantly impacted air quality across Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Thailand, and parts of the Philippines, with the most severe effects observed in June and July 2013.
 In Singapore, the Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) reached a record high of 401 on 21 June 2013, marking the first time the index exceeded 400 and entering the hazardous range.
 This level surpassed the previous record of 226 set during the 1997 haze crisis

 The Marikina River rose to 19 meters, prompting evacuations of nearby residents.

Flooding was severe in Metro Manila and surrounding provinces, with major roads submerged and water levels reaching waist or even neck-deep in areas like Cavite.

The earthquake registered a magnitude of Mw 7.2 and was caused by a reverse thrust movement along a previously unidentified fault, now known as the North Bohol Fault.

I-Involvement Comment: The 2012 Metro Manila floods, also known as the "Hagup√≠t ng Habagat" or "Bags√≠k ng Habagat," were a severe eight-day period of torrential rain and thunderstorms that affected Luzon in the Philippines from August 1 to August 8, 2012, with the worst impacts occurring between August 6 and 8
You-Involvement Comment: The event was driven by an intensified southwest monsoon (habagat), amplified by the influence of Typhoon Saola (Gener) and later Typhoon Haikui, which pulled moist air from the South China Sea and caused prolonged heavy rainfall over Metro Manila and surrounding provinces.
We-Involvement Comment:
The rainfall was exceptionally intense, with 323.4 mm recorded on August 6, 363.7 mm on August 7, and 292.6 mm on August 8 at the Science Garden station in Manila‚Äîvalues confirmed by both GTS observations and PAGASA.
 The three-day total of rainfall exceeded the mean annual rainfall in the Netherlands and had a return time of over 600 years based on historical data from 1947 to 2010, indicating an extreme event.

On 15 February 2013, a large meteoroid entered Earth's atmosphere over the southern Ural region in Russia, near Chelyabinsk, at approximately 09:20 YEKT (03:20 UTC).
 The object, estimated to be about 18 meters in diameter and weighing approximately 10,000 tonnes, approached Earth at a speed of about 19.2 km/s (68,980 km/h) on a shallow 18-degree trajectory
You-Involvement Comment: The meteor became a superbolide, briefly brighter than the Sun, with a luminosity comparable to that of the Sun (about -26.7 magnitude), and was visible across a wide area, including neighboring republics and parts of Kazakhstan.
We-Involvement Comment:
The meteor exploded in a powerful air burst at an altitude of approximately 30 kilometers (18.6 miles) above Chelyabinsk Oblast, releasing an estimated energy equivalent to 400‚Äì500 kilotonnes of TNT‚Äîroughly 30 times the energy of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
 This explosion generated a strong shock wave that caused widespread damage, shattering windows in over 7,200 buildings across six cities, damaging a factory roof, and collapsing parts of a stadium and zinc plant.

On April 17, 2013, an ammonium nitrate explosion occurred at the West Fertilizer Company storage and distribution facility in West, Texas, United States, while emergency services personnel were responding to a fire at the facility.
 The explosion, which took place at 7:50:38 p.m. CDT (UTC‚àí05:00), had the force of 7.5 to 10 tons of TNT and created a 93-foot-wide (28 m) and 12-foot-deep (3.7 m) crater where the plant had stood.
You-Involvement Comment:
he blast resulted in 15 fatalities and approximately 160 to 280 injuries, with over 150 buildings damaged or destroyed, including the West Middle School, a 50-unit apartment building, a nursing home, and numerous homes.
 The explosion was felt 80 miles away and registered as a 2.1-magnitude earthquake.
We-Involvement Comment: The fire that preceded the explosion began in the company‚Äôs fertilizer and seed building, though the initial cause of the fire remained unknown after investigators ruled out weather, natural causes, anhydrous ammonia, and a rail car containing ammonium nitrate as possible sources.
